channel.title: INfinance
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from INfinance, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: ‘I handle my dad’s finances’: My father is in a nursing home and will get $100K in compensation. What should I do with it?
item.description: “I’ve thought about CDs, money-market and mutual funds.”

item.title: Investors Are Betting on a Market Melt-Up
item.description: They have flocked to stock funds at a pace rarely seen since 2008, but some are warning that shares look expensive historically.

item.title: My wife is 9 years older than I am — but makes 50% less. Will I have to retire for her to receive my Social Security spousal benefits?
item.description: “She will probably retire nearly a decade before I do.”

item.title: ‘I’m 38 and completely broke’: I earn $50,000 a year. What professional degree will guarantee me six figures?
item.description: “I am willing to put in an extra 1 to 4 years of schooling and use student loans to pay for it.”

item.title: I juggle 18 credit cards. I would like to close 5 of them. How can I do this without ruining my credit score?
item.description: “I have very high limits, so charges barely make a blip on my credit-utilization ratio.”

item.title: The WSJ Dollar Index Falls 0.3% To 100.84
item.description: The WSJ Dollar Index was down 0.3% to 100.84 — snapping a five-trading-day winning streak.

item.title: TikTok Parent ByteDance's Valuation Rises to About $300 Billion
item.description: Investors see Trump victory as a positive with the threat of TikTok ban looming in U.S.

item.title: Trump Crypto Craze Sent Bitcoin Miners Surging, but Watch Out
item.description: Investors have long used shares in bitcoin miners to gain exposure to the digital currency, but there are better options available now.

item.title: I was invited to join a VIP investment club. It promoted bitcoin and other crypto — that’s when the trouble started.
item.description: “The people in charge, I realize now, somehow managed to manipulate a small-cap stock so the members made profits.”

item.title: For Retirees in Their 60s, the Move That Adds Years to a Nest Egg
item.description: Roth conversions allow retirees to pay taxes on their savings now, so that the money can grow tax-free in the future.
